name: Malacca
fun_fact: Fun fact: Malacca invented Satay Celup - a unique hotpot where you dip skewers into boiling spicy peanut sauce instead of soup, and it can only be found authentically in this city!

hero_dishes.name: Chicken Rice Balls
hero_dishes.description: Rice cooked in chicken stock shaped into ping-pong sized balls
hero_dishes.origin_story: Unique Malaccan invention - the only place rice balls are traditional
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Jonker Street and throughout the old town

hero_dishes.name: Nyonya Laksa
hero_dishes.description: Spicy coconut curry noodle soup with Peranakan spices
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born from 15th century Chinese-Malay fusion culture

hero_dishes.name: Satay Celup
hero_dishes.description: DIY hotpot with skewers dipped in boiling spicy peanut sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Malaccan original - found nowhere else authentically

hero_dishes.name: Ayam Pongteh
hero_dishes.description: Nyonya chicken stew with fermented soybean paste and potatoes

signature_drinks.name: Cendol
signature_drinks.description: Shaved ice with green rice flour jelly, coconut milk, and Gula Melaka
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At Jonker Street stalls, especially the famous durian cendol at Jonker 88

signature_drinks.name: Gula Melaka drinks
signature_drinks.description: Drinks sweetened with Malacca's famous palm sugar
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The distinctive caramel-rich sweetener unique to the region

food_culture_notes: Jonker Street Weekend Night Market is the heart of food scene
Baba Charlie is legendary for handmade Nyonya kuih (traditional sweets)
Peranakan culture born from 15th century Chinese-Malay marriages
Food combines Chinese, Malay, Javanese, South Indian influences

unique_modern: decorated trishaws with flowers and lights
